abstract.p: Atari, video game player from 1980's, early game cartridges and vintage Atari T-shirts are popular again; photo (Pulse column) (S)

block.p: While video game enthusiasts may be pulling all-nighters battling three-dimensional demons in the new Diablo II, more nostalgic game players are rediscovering a simpler bygone joystick: Atari. To play Pac-Man, Missile Command and other games left for extinct in the 80's, some are digging ancient Atari systems out of their closets, others are buying them on eBay (about $30). While classic cartridges like Asteroids, Combat and Space Invaders can still be bought for a couple of dollars at many electronics stores, rarer Atari games like Quadran, from 1983, can fetch up to $400 on online auctions.
''It's a big thing of my youth,'' said John Hardie, 34, an Atari collector in Valley Stream, N.Y. ''It's hard to explain. It's what I grew up with.''

The unofficial totem of the refound faith is a T-shirt bearing the Atari logo, a sort of streamlined, inverted fleur-de-lis. It is still manufactured and can be found at Urban Outfitters ($28). The ''triple track'' version (right), with a white collar and stripes around the arms, has been especially visible since DJ Qualls wore it in the film ''Road Trip'' this year.
Vintage shirts and unopened cartridges can be ordered from O'Shea Ltd., a video game retailer in Kansas City, Mo.: www.atariclassic.com.
